unnormalised: The educational journey in India is often marked by a series of certificates and achievements. It all starts with the 10th std, where you get your first big certificate, sort of a rite of passage, innit? Passing 10th with flying colours, say, above 75%, gives you a certain confidence boost.
normalised: The educational journey in India is often marked by a series of certificates and achievements. It all starts with the tenth standard, where you get your first big certificate, sort of a rite of passage, isn't it? Passing tenth with flying colors, say, above seventy five percent, gives you a certain confidence boost.

unnormalised: Then comes the crucial 12th std. This is where the stream selection matters – Science, Commerce, or Arts. Your 12th marks, esp. if you score >90%, pretty much decide which colleges you get into. Those cut-offs can be brutal! Like, for some courses in Delhi University (DU), it's like, 99% or something crazy.
normalised: Then comes the crucial twelfth standard. This is where the stream selection matters – Science, Commerce, or Arts. Your twelfth marks, especially if you score greater than ninety percent, pretty much decide which colleges you get into. Those cut-offs can be brutal! Like, for some courses in Delhi University (D-U), it's like, ninety nine percent or something crazy.

unnormalised: After 12th, the options are endless. B.A, B.Sc, B.Com – the traditional degrees are still popular. But professional courses like B.Tech and MBBS are super competitive. Getting into IITs requires cracking JEE Main and JEE Advanced with a good rank. And getting into AIIMS for MBBS needs a high NEET score. My cousin cleared NEET with a score of 650/720 this year and got a seat in a good medical college in Kerala! He was chuffed to bits.
normalised: After twelfth, the options are endless. B-A, B-Sc, B-Com – the traditional degrees are still popular. But professional courses like B-Tech and M-B-B-S are super competitive. Getting into I-I-T's requires cracking J-E-E Main and J-E-E Advanced with a good rank. And getting into A-I-I-M-S for M-B-B-S needs a high N-E-E-T score. My cousin cleared N-E-E-T with a score of six hundred and fifty divided by seven hundred and twenty this year and got a seat in a good medical college in Kerala! He was chuffed to bits.

unnormalised: These days, there are so many new-age degrees, too. Like, BBA, BCA, and even specialized courses like B.Des or B.Pharm. Some folks even do vocational courses right after 10th, like a diploma in engineering or a certification in IT skills. My younger brother got a Diploma in Mechanical Engg with 80% marks.
normalised: These days, there are so many new-age degrees, too. Like, B-B-A, B-C-A, and even specialized courses like B-Des or B-Pharm. Some folks even do vocational courses right after tenth, like a diploma in engineering or a certification in I-T skills. My younger brother got a Diploma in Mechanical Engineering with eighty percent marks.

unnormalised: Post-graduation is another ball game altogether. MBA is a classic choice for many. Cracking CAT with a good percentile (90+ usually) opens doors to IIMs. Then there are specialized masters like M.Tech, MS, or even an LLM if you're into law. Aisha got her Masters in English Literature, or an M.A. in English Lit, from JNU.
normalised: Post-graduation is another ball game altogether. M-B-A is a classic choice for many. Cracking C-A-T with a good percentile (ninety plus usually) opens doors to I-I-M's. Then there are specialized masters like M-Tech, M-S, or even an L-L-M if you're into law. Aisha got her Masters in English Literature, or an M-A in English Lit, from J-N-U.

unnormalised: PhD is the ultimate academic achievement, innit? Dr. Rakesh Kumar, a prof at IIT Bombay, got his PhD from Stanford in 2010. It opens up a whole new world of research and teaching opportunities. You get to add "Dr." before your name, which is cool.
normalised: P-h-D is the ultimate academic achievement, isn't it? Doctor Rakesh Kumar, a professor at I-I-T Bombay, got his P-h-D from Stanford in two thousand and ten. It opens up a whole new world of research and teaching opportunities. You get to add "Doctor" before your name, which is cool.

unnormalised: Certifications play a big role too, even outside formal education. Think about it - PMP certification for project management, CCNA for networking, or a digital marketing certification from Google. These add serious value to your resume and can boost your career prospects. For instance, getting a certification from AWS could get you a raise of at least 15%. These can often cost around ₹10,000-₹30,000, give or take, depending on the institute and length of the course. The main thing is to find something you are passionate about, and then work hard to achieve the relevant certification. Best of luck!
normalised: Certifications play a big role too, even outside formal education. Think about it - P-M-P certification for project management, C-C-N-A for networking, or a digital marketing certification from Google. These add serious value to your resume and can boost your career prospects. For instance, getting a certification from A-W-S could get you a raise of at least fifteen percent. These can often cost around rupee ten thousand to rupee thirty thousand, give or take, depending on the institute and length of the course. The main thing is to find something you are passionate about, and then work hard to achieve the relevant certification. Best of luck!
